column2: Surakarta features a tropical monsoon climate. The city has a lengthy wet season spanning from October through June
column3: and a relatively short dry season covering the remaining three months (July through September). On average Surakarta receives just under 2200 mm (86.6 in) of rainfall annually
column4: with its wettest months being December
column6: and February. As is common in areas featuring a tropical monsoon climate
column7: temperatures are relatively consistent throughout the year. Surakarta's average temperature is roughly 30 °C every month (86 °F).

column1: One main tourist attraction of Surakarta is the Keraton Surakarta
column3: also the Princely Javanese court of Mangkunegaran. Pasar Gede market is often visited by tourists
column4: mostly for its unique architecture and fame as the biggest traditional market in the Solo area. The Pasar Klewer is famous for its batiks in all prices and qualities
column5: while the Pasar Triwindhu located near Mangkunegaran palace specialises in antiques. Taman Sriwedari is a popular local entertainment park featuring a children's playground
column6: dangdut music performance and Wayang Wong traditional Javanese dance performance almost every night. Near the park is Radyapustaka Museum
column7: one of the oldest museums in Indonesia
column8: with a collection of Javanese cultural artefacts. The traditional batik village of Laweyan and Kampung Batik Kauman
column9: located in the southwest part of the city and the city centre respectively
column10: are famous for producing fine quality Javanese batik.
